Introduction

Lactose intolerance is a common condition characterized by abdominal pain, bloating, flatulence, and diarrhea after ingesting lactose, a disaccharide found in dairy products.  It usually occurs from lactose malabsorption by the small intestine due to a deficiency of lactase, an enzyme necessary for its breakdown.

Pathophysiology



Lactose is a disaccharide present in milk and other dairy products.  Because only monosaccharides can be absorbed by the small intestine, lactose must be hydrolyzed into its monosaccharide components.  Lactase, a brush border enzyme concentrated in epithelial cells of the small intestine, hydrolyzes lactose into glucose and galactose.  Following breakdown, the monosaccharides are fully absorbed within the small intestine.



Without lactase, undigested lactose can enter the large intestine, where colonic bacteria ferments it into short-chain fatty acids (eg, acetate, butyrate, propionate) that acidify the stool.  Hydrogen gas is also produced, leading to bloating and flatulence.  Undigested lactose also acts as an osmotic agent, drawing water into the lumen and causing osmotic diarrhea.



Lactose malabsorption from lactase deficiency can be either primary or secondary:

Primary lactose malabsorption 



  • Congenital:  a rare autosomal recessive condition in which complete lactase deficiency presents with diarrhea after birth. 
  • Acquired:  the most common cause of lactose intolerance.  This occurs due to a physiologic downregulation of lactase gene expression that occurs with aging (ie, lactase nonpersistence).  Lactase gene expression is normally increased in infancy and early childhood when milk is the primary source of nutrition.  However, gene expression naturally declines with increasing age in most ethnic groups, especially patients of Asian and African descent. 

Secondary lactose malabsorption



Secondary lactose malabsorption may occur secondary to small intestinal inflammation (eg, celiac disease, Crohn disease) or infection (eg, giardiasis) that damage the intestinal brush border.  The damaged cells slough off and are replaced by immature cells with low lactase concentrations.  Secondary lactase deficiency is often transient, lasting weeks to months.

Risk factors



Factors that increase the risk of lactose intolerance include:



  • Ethnicity:  higher prevalence of lactose intolerance among patients of Asian, African, and Hispanic descent.
  • Genetics:  congenital lactase deficiency is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
  • Gastrointestinal diseases:  Crohn disease, celiac disease, and infection can damage the small intestine and reduce lactase production.
  • Increasing age:  lactase production naturally declines over time.

Clinical presentation



Patients with lactose intolerance typically present with abdominal pain, bloating, flatulence, and possibly diarrhea within hours of ingesting lactose-containing foods.  Symptom severity may vary, depending on the amount of intestinal lactase present and the amount of lactose ingested.  Foods that are high in lactose (eg, milk, ice cream) may produce more severe symptoms relative to foods that contain less lactose (eg, cheese, yogurt).  Symptoms typically resolve with elimination of dietary lactose.  In cases of secondary lactose intolerance, the patient may report a recent history of gastroenteritis with worsening diarrhea after reintroducing dietary dairy.



Borborygmi (ie, intestinal rumbling related to bacterial production of hydrogen gas) may be appreciated on auscultation of the abdomen; however, abdominal examination is typically normal.

Diagnosis



Lactose intolerance is a clinical diagnosis that can be established in patients whose gastrointestinal symptoms (eg, abdominal pain, bloating) occur after consuming lactose products and resolve after eliminating dietary lactose.



However, if the diagnosis is uncertain, a confirmatory hydrogen breath test may be performed.  The hydrogen breath test is a noninvasive test that assesses for the presence of hydrogen in the patient's breath after ingesting standardized amount of lactose.  Human cells cannot produce hydrogen gas; therefore, the presence of hydrogen in the patient's breath is evidence of bacterial fermentation of undigested lactose.  For those with suspected secondary lactose intolerance, a diagnostic hydrogen breath test is not necessary because symptoms usually resolve within weeks as the intestinal mucosa heals.



Other laboratory findings that support the diagnosis of lactose intolerance:



  • Acidic stool pH due to the presence of fermentation products (ie, short-chain fatty acids)
  • High stool osmotic gap (eg, >125 mOsm/kg) due to the presence of undigested lactose.  The osmotic gap is calculated as 290 âˆ’ [2 (stool Na + stool K)] and is >75 mOsm/kg in all forms of osmotic diarrhea.


Imaging is generally not required for the diagnosis of lactose intolerance but may be necessary to exclude other diagnoses.

Differential diagnosis



The symptoms of lactose intolerance (eg, abdominal pain, bloating, flatulence, diarrhea) overlap with other gastrointestinal disorders, including:



  • Intolerance of other carbohydrates (eg, fructose, sorbitol):  Malabsorption of other carbohydrates can also lead to bacterial fermentation, resulting in flatulence and abdominal pain.  A thorough dietary history is essential to distinguish the cause.
  • Small intestine bacterial overgrowth:  Normally, the small intestine contains fewer bacteria compared to the large intestine, likely due to host protective factors, which if disrupted (eg, immunodeficiency, postoperative anatomic changes) can allow for bacterial overgrowth.  Excess bacteria in the small intestines can ferment carbohydrates that have yet to be digested, resulting in flatulence and diarrhea.
  • Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS):  a functional gastrointestinal disorder that presents with chronic abdominal pain and diarrhea alternating with constipation.  IBS symptoms are often related to stress and not associated with lactose ingestion.
  • Celiac disease:  a common chronic malabsorption syndrome that occurs due to an immune reaction to dietary gluten.  Patients may develop abdominal pain, flatulence, steatorrhea (due to villous atrophy and subsequent fat malabsorption), weight loss, and sometimes dermatitis herpetiformis.  Symptoms improve with strict adherence to a gluten-free diet. 
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD):  Crohn disease or ulcerative colitis can also present with abdominal pain and diarrhea, but distinguishing features include hematochezia, weight loss, and fatigue.  Patients with IBD can develop secondary lactose intolerance.
  • Gastroenteritis:  usually an acute but transient condition caused by infections (eg, viral, bacterial, or parasitic).  Patients may develop fever in addition to abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody or nonbloody diarrhea. 
  • Pancreatic insufficiency:  Patients with chronic pancreatitis may develop exocrine insufficiency, which impairs digestion of fat and protein, causing steatorrhea. 

Management



Management of patients with lactose intolerance includes:



  • Avoiding foods that are high in lactose (eg, milk, ice cream).  Most patients can tolerate foods that contain less lactose, so complete elimination of dietary lactose may not be required.  Dietary modification may only be temporary for patients who have secondary lactose malabsorption.
  • Supplementing with lactase enzyme when ingesting lactose-rich foods.
  • Maintaining adequate vitamin D and calcium intake (eg, monitoring levels, providing supplementation).

Prognosis



With dietary modification and enzyme supplementation, the prognosis of lactose intolerance is excellent.  While it is a lifelong condition for many, symptoms can be effectively controlled, allowing individuals to lead normal lives.
